message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest pyloric stenosis, which is hypertrophy of the pylorus muscle, causing obstruction of the gastric outlet. The "olive-like" mass palpated in the right upper quadrant is consistent with the hypertrophied pyloric muscle. The hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis is a result of the loss of gastric acid and potassium through prolonged vomiting. Duodenal atresia, aganglionic colon segment, and achalasia do not present with projectile vomiting and a palpable mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest hypertrophy of the pylorus muscle, known as pyloric stenosis. The firm mass palpated in the right upper quadrant is the hypertrophied pylorus, and the hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis is a result of the continued loss of hydrochloric acid and potassium in the vomitus. Duodenal atresia and aganglionic colon segment would present with bilious vomiting, and achalasia would not present with vomiting in an infant.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The non-bilious projectile vomiting after feeding, the hungry appearance after vomiting, and the palpable “olive-like” mass in the right upper quadrant are suggestive of hypertrophy of the pylorus muscle, also known as pyloric stenosis. Hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis can also be seen in this condition because of the loss of gastric acid and chloride through vomiting. The other options, duodenal atresia, aganglionic colon segment, and achalasia, have different clinical presentations and laboratory findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of non-bilious projectile vomiting, hunger after vomiting, and the presence of an olive-like mass in the right upper quadrant suggest hypertrophy of the pylorus muscle or pyloric stenosis. The hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis is also commonly seen in pyloric stenosis. Duodenal atresia presents with bilious vomiting, aganglionic colon segment presents with constipation, and achalasia presents with difficulty swallowing.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including projectile vomiting after feeding, a “olive-like” mass in the right upper quadrant, and hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, suggest hypertrophy of the pylorus muscle, which results in pyloric stenosis. Duodenal atresia presents with early bilious vomiting, and aganglionic colon segment presents with failure to pass meconium. Achalasia presents with difficulty in swallowing and regurgitation of undigested food.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms are classic for hypertrophy of the pylorus muscle, also known as pyloric stenosis, which causes projectile vomiting and is often accompanied by a palpable mass in the abdomen. Duodenal atresia would result in bilious vomiting, while aganglionic colon segment and achalasia are not typically seen in infants. The hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis is a result of loss of hydrochloric acid and potassium in the vomit.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including non-bilious projectile vomiting, still hungry after vomiting, and the palpable mass suggest hypertrophy of the pylorus muscle. Duodenal atresia and aganglionic colon segment are associated with failure to pass meconium whereas achalasia involves the esophagus and not the stomach. The laboratory findings of hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis are also commonly seen in hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including non-bilious projectile vomiting, hunger after vomiting, and a palpable mass in the right upper quadrant, suggest hypertrophy of the pylorus muscle, also known as pyloric stenosis. The hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis is a common result of vomiting. Duodenal atresia usually presents with bilious vomiting, aganglionic colon segment presents later in life, and achalasia affects the esophagus not the stomach.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest pyloric stenosis. It is characterized by the “olive-like” mass in the right upper quadrant, hypochloremic and hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis due to excessive loss of hydrochloric acid and potassium in vomit. Duodenal atresia presents with bilious vomiting, aganglionic colon segment presents with failure to pass meconium, and achalasia causes difficulty in swallowing rather than vomiting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of non-bilious projectile vomiting, a firm “olive-like” mass palpated in the right upper quadrant, and laboratory findings of hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis all suggest hypertrophy of the pylorus muscle, which causes pyloric stenosis. Duodenal atresia presents with bilious vomiting, aganglionic colon segment results in constipation and failure to pass meconium, and achalasia causes difficulty swallowing and reflux.
